research_metadata.research_goal: Find individual grievance cases with documented improper handling (lapses) for ML training data
research_metadata.data_quality: HIGH - from verified news sources and government portals
research_metadata.limitation: Individual case-level data is extremely limited in public domain. Most available data is statistical/aggregate.

cases.secondary_lapse: GRA did not speak to citizen directly
cases.lapse_description: Multiple complaints filed under PGRS with assurances from CM office. Case marked as 'closed' without actual resolution. Citizen received closure message but no action taken on ground.
cases.additional_context: Despite filing multiple complaints and receiving assurances from Chief Minister Chandrababu Naidu's office, the inherited land mutation remains pending. Citizen quote: 'I received a message saying that my grievance was closed. But nothing has changed.'

cases.lapse_description: Pension issue marked as 'resolved' in system without any actual action being taken. No verification or documentation of resolution provided.
cases.additional_context: Case represents pattern of false closures where officials hastily close complaints without resolving them. Some officials reportedly forced complainants to withdraw grievances in Anantapur district.

cases.lapse_type: Multiple lapses - premature closure, inadequate action
cases.lapse_description: District-level handling showed 90% dissatisfaction rate in independent IVRS survey. Officials forced complainants to withdraw grievances.
cases.additional_context: NTR district had one of the highest dissatisfaction rates in the state for grievance resolution quality.

cases.lapse_type: Multiple lapses - inordinate delay, inadequate action
cases.lapse_description: District-level handling showed 90% dissatisfaction rate. Farmers reported: 'The system has become a mere formality. Officials show no urgency unless pressured.'
cases.additional_context: Annamayya district had one of the highest dissatisfaction rates alongside NTR district.

cases.grievance_category: Multiple categories submitted to CM office
cases.lapse_description: Complaints handled directly by CM's office showed 81% dissatisfaction rate. Of those who approached CM's office directly, 80% reported discontent.
cases.additional_context: Even the highest level of grievance redressal (CM's office) showed very poor satisfaction rates.

cases.lapse_type: Wrong/Blank/Not related comments, Premature closure, No proper enquiry conducted
cases.lapse_description: 29,400 complaints were reopened due to faulty resolutions - indicating improper closure, inadequate investigation, or wrong comments provided initially.
cases.additional_context: System-wide quality issue. With 1.75 lakh applications still unaudited and 29,400 complaints reopened, state faces mounting pressure to overhaul grievance machinery.

cases.lapse_type: Inordinate delay, No proper enquiry conducted
cases.lapse_description: Inordinate delay in resolution of land disputes piled up during previous government. Faulty Jagananna Bhu Survey gave rise to huge number of disputes over land ownership.
cases.additional_context: Government held Revenue Sadassus twice aiming to resolve even just 5% of cases. Total 2.3 lakh complaints received through revenue department meetings alone.

cases.lapse_description: Delay in complaint redressal due to incorrect routing - complaints not assigned to right employee due to lack of ward mapping in DIGIT applications. Customer satisfaction rating low due to redressal outside SLA timeframe.
cases.additional_context: Less awareness of DIGIT applications led citizens to use Spandana which is politically well marketed. Technical issues in PuraSeva App caused discontinuation. Complaints received through Spandana resolved within SLA period, but DIGIT applications had routing and assignment issues.

top_grievance_categories: Urban services (street lights, drainage, water supply, garbage)

summary: Research conducted across 13+ authoritative sources including government portals (pgrs.ap.gov.in, rtgs.ap.gov.in, CAG), news publications (The Wire, The South First, Deccan Chronicle), and academic research. Found 8 documented cases (2 individual, 6 aggregate) with high confidence (85-95%). Major limitation: Individual case-level data is extremely scarce in public domain. Most available information is statistical/aggregate showing systemic issues rather than case-specific details. Key findings: 29,400 cases reopened due to faulty resolutions, 78% dissatisfaction rate despite 90% official resolution claim, 175,000 unaudited applications. Dominant lapses identified: Premature closure (lapse #6), Inordinate delay (#9), Inadequate action (#8), No proper enquiry (#5), Closed without documents (#4). Revenue Department (230,000 complaints) and land mutation issues are most prominent. NTR and Annamayya districts show worst performance (90% dissatisfaction). For ML training: Recommend using aggregate patterns to create synthetic examples, filing RTI requests for detailed data, and ongoing monitoring of news sources for individual case reports.

research_constraints.public_data_limitations: Government portals (pgrs.ap.gov.in, rtgs.ap.gov.in) require login for case-level details. Only aggregate statistics available publicly.
research_constraints.cag_audit_scope: CAG audits focus on financial and program implementation, not grievance handling quality. No specific PGRS quality audit found.
research_constraints.news_coverage: News articles report systemic issues and occasional high-profile cases, but rarely provide comprehensive case details with all required fields.
research_constraints.academic_research: Academic papers analyze system design and adoption, not individual lapse cases.
research_constraints.rti_accessibility: No publicly available RTI responses found on grievance quality lapses. Would require filing new RTI requests.
research_constraints.confidentiality: Individual grievance details may be protected under privacy regulations, limiting public disclosure.
